To run:

```
erl
```

then in the Erlang shell:

```
c("day5_test.erl").

day5_test:run([3,0,4,0,99]).
# Input printed as output

day5_test:run([1002,4,3,4,33]).
# [1002,4,3,4,99]

c("day5_test_part_2.erl").

day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_9_8_9.csv").
# - Using position mode, consider whether the input is equal to 8; output 1 (if it is) or 0 (if it is not).
day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_9_7_9.csv").
# - Using position mode, consider whether the input is less than 8; output 1 (if it is) or 0 (if it is not).
day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_3_1108.csv").
# - Using immediate mode, consider whether the input is equal to 8; output 1 (if it is) or 0 (if it is not).
day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_3_1107.csv").
# - Using immediate mode, consider whether the input is less than 8; output 1 (if it is) or 0 (if it is not).

day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_12_6_12.csv").
#  output 0 if the input was zero or 1 if the input was non-zero
day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_3_1105.csv").
#  output 0 if the input was zero or 1 if the input was non-zero

day5_test_part_2:run("../data/3_21_1008.csv").
# ask for a single number. The program will then output 999 if the input value is below 8, output 1000 if the input value is equal to 8, or output 1001 if the input value is greater than 8.

day5_test_part_2:run("../data_part_2.csv").
Input: 5
Output: 7731427
 ```
